subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: Rarely used in Chinese. The variant form {{zh-l|é¯°}} is more often used for the word [[catfish]].

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wp|lang=ja|ã‚¢ãƒ¦|é®}} {{wp|Ayu}} [[File:Ayu_no_Shioyaki.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|é®}} (''ayu'', ''ai''): the '''[[ayu]]''' or '''[[sweetfish]]'''.]]
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ã‚ã‚†}} From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=ã‚ã‚†|-}} of uncertain derivation. * One commonly encountered etymology suggests that ''ayu'' may derive from {{m|ja|é¥—|tr=ae||[[host]]ing someone to a [[meal]]}}, in reference to the way that this fish may be used in Shinto [[offering]]s. However, this would have been pronounced ''ape'' in ancient times, and while this ''ape'' did later become ''ahe'', and a shift from ''-he'' to ''-ye'' did occur in many terms during the {{w|Muromachi period}}{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}, the word ''ayu'' in reference to the fish appeared in the ''{{w|Nihon Shoki}}'' (720 {{CE}}), and is thus too old for this shift to have occurred. * Another common etymology states that ''ayu'' may be from extinct {{w|Old Japanese}} term {{m|ja|è½ã‚†|tr=ayu||to [[fall]], as nuts from a tree; to [[flow]] down, as [[liquid]] in a [[stream]]}}, in reference to the way that ''ayu'' swim [[downstream]] to [[spawn]] in the [[autumn]].'''1988''': ã‚ã¦å­—ã®ãŠã‚‚ã—ã‚é›‘å­¦ (''Interesting Ateji Trivia'', in Japanese), Freelance Trivia Writers, p.46, Nagaokashoten, Ltd. Some referencesGogen Allguide, http://gogen-allguide.com/a/ayu_sakana.html suggest that this is not very eventful and that this etymology is therefore unlikely. However, there are terms specific to the ''ayu'' downstream migration, such as {{m|ja|è½é®|tr=ochiayu||''ayu'' [[migrate|migrating]] downstream to spawn}} and {{m|ja|é®è½ã¤|tr=ayuotsu||''ayu'' migrating downstream to spawn}}, suggesting that this event has been culturally important enough that the {{m|ja||è½ã‚†|tr=ayu}} derivation may be [[plausible]]. * Alternatively, this term may be borrowed from {{bor|ja|ain|sort=ã‚ã‚†|ã‚¢ã‚¤|tr=ay||[[arrow]]}} in reference to how fast the fish moves. See also obsolete Japanese reading ''ai'' below. The kanji spelling {{ja-l||é®}} in reference to [[sweetfish]] is specific to Japan, probably in reference to the way the fish ({{ja-l|é­š}}) stakes out its territory ({{ja-l|å }}). There is another tale wherein {{w|Empress JingÅ«}} caught an ''ayu'' and thereby prophesied (also spelled {{ja-l||å }}) the outcome of a battle, but this is likely a [[folk etymology]]. In China and elsewhere, the {{ja-l||é®}} character refers instead to [[catfish]]. The kanji spelling {{ja-l|å¹´é­š}} is in reference to the common one-year [[lifespan]] of this fish. The kanji spelling {{ja-l|é¦™é­š}} is in reference to its [[sweet]]-tasting [[flesh]].

subSections.title: Noun
Derived terms
Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ã‚ã„}}
Obsolete variant of ''ayu'' pronunciation. May have been the original pronunciation.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: Found in some compounds. Generally not used on its own.

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ãªã¾ãš}}
The kanji spelling {{lang|ja|é®}} in reference to [[sweetfish]] is specific to Japan. In China and elsewhere, the {{lang|ja|é®}} character refers instead to [[catfish]].<ref name="KDJ"/> See the {{ja-l|é¯°}} entry for more detail about the Japanese term ''namazu''.
